lines:
/1916

Jarmary 18, 1927

Mr. Kwan, Sans Sing 
11 Rue du Marechal Yoch 
Piantsin, China

My dear Kuant

A happy and prosperous New Year to you and yours., Perhaps 
this seems lilce a peculiar wish in view of the distressed state of your 
country at this moment and the natural anxiety you must all be feeling in 
these somewhat uncertain and hectic days. But the wish is there anyway. 
and it carries with it the hope that out of this chaos will come stability, 
strength, and a united nation dealing with its citizens and the other ne- . 
tions of the world with justice and honor and to the lasting benefit of all.

A curious thing happened recently which serves as the prime 
motive of this letter. A year ago you sent me a scroll for a Christmas 
present, I believe but the exact nature of which, in viey of the lack of 
explanation on your part, I could never quite understand the several 
members of the Sun family, who have been my wards for a number of years 
and for part of that time members of my own family circle, wore called on 
by me for light on the subject but without success. No one seened able to 
tell me just what the seroll signified or what it actually was.

I have two new wards this year, the son and daughter of Ad -
miral Psai, Ping-kan of Peking. During the holidays they were at my house 
for a part of the time, and I thought it worth while to test them out on 
the seroll in deation. The daughter, an exceptionally bright young 
cirl, was able to clear up the mystery and with evident entirasissa explain -
ed just what the scroll meant, its great age, and its greater value. Need -
less to say the information was most welcome and made me realize that I 
possessed a real treasure, thanks to your most friendly generosity.

It must seem to you a dit queer for me to acknowledge my in -
debtedness at this lase date, but I am doing so, and gladly none the less, 
at the same time offering sy apologies for my density and seeming, indiffer -
ence in the past. of the numerous Chinese articles in my house, which have 
come to me from time to time and all of which have their special value, I 
think I can honestly say that none now possesses a greater value in my sicht 
than your umsual ift. Nany and hearty thanks.

Thy don't you write us once in a while and keep us informed 
of your whereabouts and doings. Don't forget that you still have a big 
place in our hearts and esteem, and your many friends, especially this one 
who is writing, would rejoice reatly to know more definitely and at first 
hand about you.
